item.title: Chinese Stocks Advance as Preliminary Trade Deal Eases Tensions
item.description: Chinese stocks rose on Wednesday, after the world’s two largest economies agreed on a plan to reduce trade tensions following a two-day meeting in London.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu, Winnie Hsu

item.title: Being a Bully on Trade Won’t Work Longer Term, Lagarde Warns
item.description: There’s no longer-term advantage to being a bully on global commerce, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde on June 5.

item.title: North Korea Appears to Have Added to Its Nuclear Complex
item.description: North Korea appears to have constructed a new building within its main nuclear complex, satellite imagery showed, in what could be an additional enrichment facility to ramp up the country’s ability to produce nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kim Jae-Hwan/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images) Photographer: SOPA Images/SOPA Images

item.title: Pentagon Slashes in Half Its Request for Air Force F-35s
item.description: The Air Force has cut in half its request to Congress for its signature F-35s, dealing a blow to Lockheed Martin Corp., the top US defense contractor.
item.dc:creator: Roxana Tiron, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: A US Air Force F35A fighter jet. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Downtown LA Under Curfew as Newsom Warns of Trump Overreach
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom accused President Donald Trump of misusing his power by mobilizing troops in Los Angeles and warned other states to prepare for similar unrest, as protests over immigration raids stretched into a fifth night and led to a curfew in parts of the city’s downtown.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: California National Guard members stand guard outside the Federal Building as protests continue in response to federal immigration operations in Los Angeles on June 10, 2025. US President Donald Trump on June 9 ordered active-duty Marines into Los Angeles, vowing those protesting immigration arrests would be "hit harder" than ever. Protests in Los Angeles, home to a large Latino population, broke out on June 6, triggered by immigration raids that resulted in dozens of arrests of what authorities say are illegal migrants and gang members. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Kirchner’s Ban From Office Marks New Chapter for Argentina
item.description: Argentina’s top court sidelined former President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner from elections, likely ushering in a new political era in South America’s second biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Former Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner Photographer: Tomas Cuesta/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Faces More Challenges Even as Lawsuit Paused
item.description: After more than two years of relative political stability in Malaysia, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim faces multiple hurdles that could fuel discontent within his ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim

item.title: Philippine Senators Send Duterte Impeachment Back to House
item.description: Prospects for a Senate trial of Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte were thrown into doubt late Tuesday after senators voted to return the articles of impeachment to the House to ensure they don’t breach the constitution.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon, Ditas B Lopez

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Charles M. Vella/SOPA Images/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Poised to Repeal Biden Curbs on Power Plant Pollution
item.description: The Trump administration will propose scrapping Biden-era climate mandates requiring the nation’s power plants to curb planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions as soon as Wednesday, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Steam rises from a power plant in Adamsville, Alabama.

item.title: National Guard Providing Security for ICE Officers, US Says
item.description: National Guard troops are now protecting Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers in and around Los Angeles, marking an expansion of their duties since being deployed by President Donald Trump this week.
item.dc:creator: Isabela Fleischmann

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 10: Protesters gather in front of California National Guard soldiers and LAPD officers guarding the Edward R. Roybal Federal building as protests continue in Los Angeles following four days of clashes with police after a series of immigration raids on June 10, 2025 in Los Angeles, California. Tensions in the city remain high after the Trump administration called in the National Guard against the wishes of city leaders. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Tariffs Can Stay in Effect Longer, Appeals Court Says
item.description: Donald Trump can continue to enforce his global tariffs for now, a federal appeals court held in a win for the president on one of his signature economic policies.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Ken Cedeno/UPI

item.title: Traders See Cooling US-China Tensions Sparking Cautious Gains
item.description: Asia’s traders mostly shrugged off news of a preliminary US-China trade deal, with most looking for more details from the accord before making investment plans.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu

item.title: NJ’s Sherrill, Ciattarelli Win Primaries in Governor’s Race
item.description: New Jersey voters have chosen Mikie Sherrill to face off against Jack Ciattarelli, pitting a moderate Democrat against a Trump-endorsed Republican in the first gubernatorial election since last year’s presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Sri Taylor

media:content.media:description: Jack Ciattarelli departs after casting his ballot during early voting in 2021.

item.title: US and China Agree Plan to Restore Trade Truce
item.description: The US and China agreed to a preliminary plan to ease trade tensions, which could revive the flow of sensitive goods between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick at Lancaster House in London on June 10.

item.title: NJ Congresswoman Indicted Over Scuffle at ICE Facility, US Says
item.description: A federal grand jury indicted a Democratic House lawmaker from Newark, New Jersey, over her confrontation with US immigration officers outside a private detention facility that is key to the Trump administration’s mass deportation plans, according to a prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Representative LaMonica McIver

item.title: Key Lawmaker Questions Hegseth Decision to Slash Test Office
item.description: A top House Republican who oversees Pentagon spending expressed surprise and concern about Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s order last month to slash nearly half the staff of the Pentagon’s test oversight agency, even as the US embarks on major military initiatives including the F-47 fighter and the Golden Dome defensive system.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: Ken Calvert

item.title: Associated Press Challenges Ruling Limiting White House Access
item.description: The Associated Press is challenging a ruling that allowed President Donald Trump to exclude the news agency from “restricted” spaces like the Oval Office and Air Force One.
item.dc:creator: Steve Stroth

media:content.media:description: A “Gulf of America” poster behind Donald Trump during an executive order signing ceremony in the Oval Office of the White House in March.

item.title: US Assails Sanctions by UK, Other Allies on Israeli Ministers
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio rebuked five allies over sanctions they imposed on two members of Israel’s cabinet as fissures between the US and its partners widen over the war in Gaza and the treatment of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, during a meeting with US President Donald Trump and Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Relations between Washington and Berlin are tense amid issues ranging from trade imbalances to support for Kyiv.

item.title: Gabbard Warns Global Nuclear Annihilation Is Closer Than Ever
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard, the US director of national intelligence, released a video Tuesday warning that the world is closer to nuclear war than ever and accusing unnamed political elites of trying to foment conflict between world powers.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard

item.title: Starlink Is Best for Rural Airports, Not So Much for Urban Ones, Cruz Says
item.description: Urban airports should use fiber-optic communications while Elon Musk’s Starlink satellite service may be better for rural ones, Senator Ted Cruz said.
item.dc:creator: Mel Ambaye

media:content.media:description: A Starlink satellite-internet communication system antenna and router on a rooftop in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday, March 11, 2025. European Defense Commissoiner Andrius Kubilius expressed confidence that the EU would be able to replace the Starlink satellite communications system quickly in Ukraine if owner Elon Musk were to pull the plug.

item.title: Marines Arrive in LA as Tensions Grow Over Immigration Raids
item.description: Marines deployed by President Donald Trump arrived in the Los Angeles area with orders to protect federal property and officers, as the city is gripped by tensions over anti-deportation protests.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Alicia Clanton, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators in front of California National Guard members outside the Federal Building in Los Angeles on June 9.

item.title: ABC News Drops Correspondent Terry Moran Over Anti-Trump Post
item.description: Walt Disney Co.’s ABC News division said it parted ways with Washington-based correspondent Terry Moran over comments he made on social media over the weekend about President Donald Trump and White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller.
item.dc:creator: Chris Palmeri

media:content.media:description: Terry Moran

item.title: US Judge to Weigh Limiting Military Troops in LA on Thursday
item.description: California’s bid to limit military involvement in the Los Angeles immigration protests will be taken up by a judge Thursday, meaning that a pullback by the Trump administration before then is unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Sunday, June 8, 2025. The deployment of National Guard troops by President Donald Trump over the weekend, despite the objections of state and city officials, led to growing friction between local leaders and the administration.

item.title: US Seeks to Halt Abrego Garcia Deportation Case After His Return
item.description: Days after Kilmar Abrego Garcia was brought back to the US to face human smuggling charges, the Trump administration asked a federal court to halt a lawsuit seeking answers over why the US hadn’t facilitated his return following his wrongful deportation to El Salvador.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A picture of Kilmar Abrego Garcia during a news conference at Cannon House Office Building in Washington, DC, on April 9. Photographer: Alex Wong/Getty Images

item.title: Argentina’s Top Court Bans Kirchner From Office for Life
item.description: Argentina’s Supreme Court upheld former President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner’s fraud conviction, ratifying her sentence to six years in prison as well as a lifelong ban on holding public office, according to the court ruling reviewed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Former Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner

item.title: How NYC’s Ranked-Choice Voting System Looms Over Mayoral Race
item.description: New York City’s mayoral contest has had plenty of drama ahead of the June 24 vote. The incumbent mayor, Eric Adams, decided not to participate in the Democratic primary in the wake of a corruption scandal and is running instead as an independent. The front-runner, former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, is attempting a political comeback after leaving office in 2021 following multiple allegations of sexual harassment. And Cuomo’s closest challenger for the Democratic nomination is Zohran Mamdani,
item.dc:creator: Stacie Sherman, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: New York City mayoral candidates Adrienne Adams, from left, Brad Lander, Jessica Ramos, Zellnor Myrie, Andrew Cuomo, Whitney Tilson, Zohran Mamdani, Michael Blake, and Scott Stringer during a mayoral Democratic primary debate in New York, on June 4. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/AP Photo/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Defends UK Economic Choices as She Touts Public Spending
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer’s government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves

item.title: Hydrogen Tax Credit Rescue ‘On the Table,’ GOP Senator Says
item.description: The Senate is considering a plan to save a lucrative tax credit for the production of hydrogen that would be scrapped in the tax-and-spending mega bill passed by the House, key Republicans said.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: A liquid green hydrogen plant in Woodbine, Georgia.

item.title: Mexico’s President Pushes Back on Claim She Encouraged LA Violence
item.description: US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem accused Claudia Sheinbaum of encouraging anti-deportation protests in Los Angeles, drawing a rare rebuke from the Mexican leader who has sought to maintain cordial relations with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum

item.title: Education Secretary Says Harvard May See Grants Restored
item.description: Education Secretary Linda McMahon said that Harvard and other universities could get some of the federal funding cut by the Trump administration restored if they change their policies.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: US education secretary Linda McMahon
